description.en:
The course deals with main 20th century theoretical approaches of  power, communication, ideology and discourse, wellknown authorities (Dijk, Laclau, Schmitt, Reis etc) and links between their thoughts and ideas. Comparing concepts like: ideology,  politics, discourse,  , power, communication etc. Main idea to explore how in contemporary media age power relation are  established through communication, "soft power" 
In homeworks students are required to exert learned skills for the analyses of concrete sociopolitical phenomena.
description.et: Kursusel käsitletakse 20 sajandi peamisi teoreetilisi lähenemisi võimule, kommunikatsiooile ja ideoloogia ning diskursusele (Dijk, Laclau, Schmitt etc). Peamise eesmärgina seame kaasaja meedia ja võimusuhete analüsi.

objectives.en: The main purpose of this course is to develop skills for analysing and comprehending contemporary sociopolitical phenomena.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on arendada tänapäevaste sotsio-poliitiliste fenomenide analüüsioskust.

objectives.en: Throughout the course the students will read and discuss topics like identity and ideology; political communication; discourse and ideology; concept of power ; semiotic mechanism of constructing identities etc.
objectives.et: Kursuse jooksul tudengid loevad ja arutavad teemade üle nagu identifikatsioon ja ideoloogia, poliitiline kommunikatsioon, diskursus ja ideoloogia, võimu kontseptsioonid ja semiootilised identiteediloome mehhanismid

learning_outcomes.et:
Tudengid peaksid oskama:
1) identifitseerima ja analüüsima tähistamispraktikate ning erinevate ideoloogiliste süsteemide vahekorda
2)mõistma kommunikatsiooni rolli kaasaja identiteetidde kujunemisel
3) määratlema semiootilise analüüsi objektina võimusuhteid
4) määratlema 20 sajandi peamised suunad võimuküsimustele

independent_work.et:
In case of possible general limitations of COVID 19, all lectures and seminars will take place online. This will be announced at the time the restrictions are imposed.

1) Report of a) online lectures or b) analysis of social phenomena. 
a.     Report of online lectures consists: a) group of students (3-4 students in one group) needs to send to lecturer a written overview (min 1200 words) about one online lecture(s) (preliminary list of lecture is in SIS, but it is be better when students will find new online lectures from different universities webpages ) and b) makes oral presentation in the class. The work should consist of a critical overview about these online lectures. Those academic web-based lectures represent different (and sometimes contradictory) perspectives thus students have to generate pro and contra arguments and present their own opinion. Students need to: outline 3 main arguments of the lecture, relate those ideas with their own examples and/or previous knowledge and write one question/critical comment about the lecture. Other groups have to actively participate in discussion. Web-based learning is meant to supplement ideas discussed in lectures/seminars, online lectures should provoke critical analysis and synthesis of different ideas. Each group has 15 minutes for presentation and 5-10 for questions.
b.    Analysis of socio-political phenomenon: students do homework in a group (about 3-4 people), where they analyze a social phenomenon in the light of the theories presented in the lecture. Students present a) a written summary of homework (min. 1200 words) and send it to the lecturer, and b) introduce the main arguments of the analysis in the seminar. In homework, students must justify: the choice of the phenomenon to be studied, the chosen method of analysis and the main research results. It is also necessary to demonstrate the ability to critically relate to the chosen material and to find connections between your analysis and other topics of the course.is meant to supplement ideas discussed in lectures/seminars, online lectures should provoke critical analysis and synthesis of different ideas. Each group have 15 minutes for presentation and 5-10 for questions.  

2) Reading seminar's texts. Students have to differentiate the key points of the article and synthesize it with his/her previous knowledge and own opinion. Students should be able to answer questions about seminar's texts. Questions are uploaded in SIS. Students will also send to the lecturer written answers for two questions (before or after seminar). If a student can't participate in a seminar then the student will send answers for all questions about seminar text.

description.et:
Report (+oral presentation) of online lecture/analysis of social phenomenon (30% of grade), for grading we take into account following points:
*	Critical analysis, 
*	Connections with previous knowledge and student's own opinion 
*	The reflection of how student's understandings have developed during the course

Exam (written)
-Correct use of terms and concepts (if you use terms that were introduced during the course with some other meaning, then a corresponding explanation is needed)
-Application of the texts read during the course (please use the relevant reading materials of the course for arguing)
-The use of additional sources and proof of their relevance for the topic (use at least some other secondary sources that we've not discussed in the course)
-Logical argumentation and clear connections between different ideas
-Originality (a fuzzy criteria for sure, what is meant under that is that you'd provide the background for what has been said before about the point you're discussing and departing from that, suggest your own synthetic or new solution or view-point to the topic)
-Scientifically correct presentation of the text (clear demarcation of your own thoughts and those of the others, a unified reference system and everything else that is proper to the scientific text)

E - the argumentation of the text hard to follow, no relevant references, the text is unstructured and the presentation does not fully follow the academic standards
D - the central concepts irrelevant or not well defined, larger gaps in binding different parts of the text together, the theoretical works not fully relevant, the text lacks originality
C - the use of concepts not fully consistent, the line of argumentation tracable but further comments needed, problems with the integrity of the text
B - correct use of terms, the theotretical texts used relevant for the topic, original ideas present, minor gaps in argumentation, presentation or structuring of the text
A - theoretical texts used for the analysis relevant for the topic, the concepts used in a well-defined and understandable meaning, the argumentation clear and well-structured, the author's own synthesis original, scientifically correct presentation of the text

grade_preconditions.et:
Participation in seminar, homework
Students who cannot participate in seminars will send answers for all questions about seminar-texts. The questions and texts students will find in SIS.

grade_evaluation.et:
Final mark: Participation in seminar (10%) + homework 30 % + exam (written) 60%. Exam  include both course material and seminar texts.  In case of restrictions of COVID 19 the final  exam can be change with final essay.
Student can get max. 100 points; written exam gives 60 points,  analysis of online lecture or social political phenomenon gives  30 points and participation in seminars (10%). Participation on seminars and groupwork is precondition for final result of assessment. For grading, a student must have done all 3. Min. points for passing are: oral examination E,  report of online lecture or analysis of social political phenomenon  E .

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)
